string-array.name: quotes
string-array.item: "Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work."-Aristotle
"Dignity does not consist in possessing honors, but in deserving them."-Aristotle
"You will never do anything in this world without courage. It is the greatest quality of the mind next to honor."-Aristotle
"The life of money making is one undertaken under compulsion, and wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking; for it is merely useful and for the sake of something else."-Aristotle
"Knowledge, if it does not determine action, is dead to us."-Plotinus
"Great deeds are usually wrought at great risks."-Herodotus
"Haste in every business brings failures."-Herodotus
"Beware the barrenness of a busy life."-Demosthenes
"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing."-Demosthenes
"Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants."-Epictetus
"Make the best use of what's in your power and take the rest as it happens."-Epictetus
"A good decision is based on knowledge and not numbers."-Plato
"Better a little which is well done, than a great deal imperfectly."-Plato
"The beginning is the most important part of the work."-Plato
"Apply yourself both now and in the next life. Without effort, you cannot be prosperous. Though the land be good, you cannot have an abundant crop without cultivation."-Plato
"He who is not a good servant will not be a good master."-Plato
"As the builders say, the larger stones do not lie well without the lesser."-Plato
"Man is the measure of all things."-Protagoras
"Man is the dream of a shadow."-Pindar
"As mortals we should behave as mortals."-Euripides
"Man: one who thinks of what he sees."-Plato
"It is not possible to know medicine without knowing what a human is."-Hippocrates
"What a wonderful being is the man if he is a man."-Menander
"We became men once and one cannot become twice."-Epicurus
"Man is a microcosm."-Democritus
"Man is naturally deceitful ever, in every way!"-Aristophanes
"Most people are bad."-Bias of Priene
"World is decay, life is perception."-Democritus
"This world, which is the same for all, has not been made by any god or man, but it always has been, is, and will be an ever living fire."-Heraclitus
"One word brings another."-Euripides
"There are countless worlds both born and perishable."-Democritus
"Place is the greatest thing, as it contains all things."-Thales of Miletus
"Nothing bad is without something good."-Ancient Greek phrase
"Pleasure, a most mighty lure to evil."-Plato
"The good can never mix with the evil."-Euripides
"The just man is most free from disturbance, while the unjust is full of the utmost disturbance."-Epicurus
"Life is short and Art long; the opportunity fleeting, experience deceitful, and judgment difficult."-Hippocrates
"Nobody lives the life he chooses to live."-Menander
"Like in a statue, all parts of a life must be beautiful."-Socrates
"How sweet is life when fortune is not envious."-Menander
"Life is short."-Euripides
"The art of life is more like the wrestler's art than the dancer's, in respect of this, that it should stand ready and firm to meet onsets which are sudden and unexpected."-Marcus Aurelius
"Death is nothing to us. Because something which is decomposed has no senses while something without senses is nothing to us."-Epicurus
"Better a bad life than a good death."-Euripides
"If gods do evil, they are not gods."-Euripides
"Nothing is clear to men about the gods."-Euripides
"If it’s not right, don’t do it; if it’s not true, don’t say it."-Marcus Aurelius
"The “right” is nothing more than what benefits the powerful."-Plato
"A wrongdoer is often a man who has left something undone, not always one who has done something."-Marcus Aurelius
"What Zeus? Do not trifle. There is no Zeus."-Aristophanes
"We know nothing for sure. Because the truth is hidden in the deep."-Democritus
"The words of the truth are simple."-Aeschylus
"Everything flows, nothing stands still."-Heraclitus
"Pleasures are transient, honors are immortal."-Periander of Corinth
"Knowing that human happiness never remains long in the same place."-Herodotus
"And you, old man, we are told you prospered once."-Homer
"The universe is change; our life is what our thoughts make it."-Marcus Aurelius
"Do not act as if you are going to live ten thousand years. The inevitable hangs over you. As long as you live, while it is in your power, be good."-Marcus Aurelius
"The now is a sort of a middle thing."-Aristotle
"Know the right time."-Pittacus of Mytilene
"Respond on time."-Periander of Corinth
"Life is short and Art long; the opportunity fleeting, experience deceitful, and judgment difficult."-Hippocrates
"Time is the healer of all inevitable ills."-Menander
"Time is that wherein there is opportunity, and opportunity is that wherein there is no great time"-Hippocrates
"Time will explain it all. He is a talker, and needs no questioning before he speaks."-Euripides
"Use time sparingly."-Chilon of Sparta
"Since life is short, don’t make it long with bad deeds."-Thales of Miletus
"A huge tree can tower from a tiny seed."-Aeschylus
"If you want to live a life without stress, consider whatever is going to happen in the future as if it has already happened"-Epictetus
"The old man has been young, whilst it is unknown if the young man will reach old age."-Democritus
"Everything comes from earth and everything ends in earth."-Xenophanes
"AWe are indebted to our parents for living, but to our teachers for living well."-Alexander the Great
"To think, to see, to understand, to show the arse, to trick, to suspect the worst, to question everything."-Aristophanes
"Practice is everything."-Aeschylus
"Better be a late learner than an ignorant."-Socrates
"Three things support the perfection of a man: character, learning and practice."-Plato
"Education needs these three: natural endowment, study, practice."-Aristotle
"If you do not hit the clay, you cannot make tile."-Archytas
"The beginning of everything is atoms and void, and everything else is perception."-Democritus
"Things do not look the same when viewed from far or near."-Euripides
"He who is close to Zeus is close to thunder."-Aesop
"For the wise is easy to go anywhere. Because the whole world is home for a good soul."-Democritus
"The beginning is half of everything."-Plato
"In the beginning there was chaos."-Hesiod
"Wickedness and injustice are intentional."-Aristotle
"Slaves and master could never be friends."-Plato
"Soon, you will forget everything, and soon everybody will forget you."-Marcus Aurelius
"One cannot evade destiny."-Ancient Greek phrase
"Much learning does not teach the mind."-Heraclitus
"Everything in excess is opposed to nature."-Hippocrates
"The first and greatest victory is to conquer yourself; to be conquered by yourself is of all things most shameful and vile."-Plato
"Nobody loves anybody more than himself."-Menander
"Character is destiny."-Heraclitus
"Don’t ask who is now, but who he has always been."-Aristotle
"Character lies in polite and friendly speaking."-Aesop
"It’s not easy to change a bad character."-Menander
"Habit is second nature."-Aristotle
"Man is by nature a political animal."-Aristotle
"Friendship is one soul living in two bodies."-Aristotle
"Happiness comes from the soul, like unhappiness."-Democritus
"Each art must use its tools, each body its soul."-Aristotle
"Mind is the swiftest of things, for it runs through everything."-Thales of Miletus
"The opinions of men are toys for boys."-Heraclitus
"Nothing is easier than self-deceit. For what a man wishes to be true, he generally believes to be true."-Demosthenes
"A fool laughs even when there is nothing funny."-Pittacus of Mytilene
"Don't laugh too much, neither with many things, nor too loud."-Epictetus
"Beauty is better than any recommendation letter."-Aristotle
"Who is happy? This is a person, who has a healthy body, is dowered with peace of mind and cultivates his talents."-Thales of Miletus
"Do not trust good luck."-Chilon of Sparta
"Men have made an idol of Fortune as an excuse for their own lack of willpower."-Democritus
"The unlucky man will be bitten even by a sheep."-Aesop
"Nobody can escape destiny."-Plato
"Donkeys prefer garbage to gold."-Heraclitus
"In all things of nature there is something of the marvelous."-Aristotle
"If I were not Alexander, I should wish to be Diogenes."-Alexander the Great
"And you, son Brutus?"-Julius Caesar
"No one likes one whom he fears."-Aristotle
"One who thinks right is better than myriads who think wrong."-Plato
"To the strongest!"-Alexander the Great
"War is a school for virtue."-Aristotle
"Virtue consists not in avoiding wrong-doing, but in having no want for it."-Democritus
"The continent man is not he who avoids pleasure, but having tasted it, is not carried to excess."-Aristippus
"No one is free if he cannot subdue himself."-Epictetus
"Whoever knows about tragedy, knows about epics too."-Aristotle,
"The investigation of the meaning of words is the beginning of wisdom."-Antisthenes
"Medicine heals the body and wisdom removes the suffering from the souls."-Democritus
"That man is wise who can say what he wants in a minimum of words."-Aristophanes
"We must help the poor, not encourage idleness."-Solon
"I know that I know nothing."-Socrates
"It is better to conceal ignorance than to expose it."-Heraclitus
"Women are more envious and more querulous than men."-Aristotle
"You will not be tolerated if you are successful."-Aeschylus
"A man completely enslaved to money will never be just."-Democritus
"The madness of love is the greatest of the blessings of the gods."-Plato
"We are indebted to our parents for living, but to our teachers for living well."-Alexander the Great
"When the lamp goes off, all the women are the same."-Diogenes
"Put more trust in integrity of character than in an oath."-Solon
"Don’t trust everybody."-Pittacus of Mytilene
"Hard work is the father of good reputation."-Ancient Greek proverb
"Hear much, speak to the point."-Bias of Priene
"Do not let your tongue outrun your mind."-Chilon of Sparta
"Speaking is the shadow of action."-Democritus
"Helen? Ship destroyer, men destroyer, city destroyer."-Aeschylus

string-array.name: favorites
string-array.item: "The fundamental cause of the trouble is that in the modern world the stupid are cocksure while the intelligent are full of doubt." - Bertrand Russell
"Of all forms of caution, caution in love is perhaps the most fatal to true happiness." - Bertrand Russell
"To fear love is to fear life, and those who fear life are already 3-parts dead." - Bertrand Russell
"I would never die for my beliefs because I might be wrong." - Bertrand Russell
"A stupid man's report of what a clever man says can never be accurate, because he unconsciously translates what he hears into something he can understand." - Bertrand Russell
"Science may set limits to knowledge, but should not set limits to imagination." - Bertrand Russell
"Love is wise, hatred is foolish." - Bertrand Russell
"Men are born ignorant, not stupid; they are made stupid by education." - Bertrand Russell
"Whoever wishes to become a philosopher must learn not to be frightened by absurdities." - Bertrand Russell
"Do not fear to be eccentric in opinion, for every opinion now accepted was once eccentric." - Bertrand Russell
"There are two motives for reading a book; one, that you enjoy it; the other, that you can boast about it." - Bertrand Russell
"Fear is the main source of superstition, and one of the main sources of cruelty. To conquer fear is the beginning of wisdom." - Bertrand Russell
"The hardest thing to learn in life is which bridge to cross and which to burn." - Bertrand Russell
"It's easy to fall in love. The hard part is finding someone to catch you." - Bertrand Russell

"To teach how to live without certainty, and yet without being paralyzed by hesitation, is perhaps the chief thing that philosophy, in our age, can still do for those who study it." - Bertrand Russell
"Most people would sooner die than think; in fact, they do so." - Bertrand Russell
"It is the preoccupation with possessions, more than anything else, that prevents us from living freely and nobly." - Bertrand Russell
"Those who have never known the deep intimacy and the intense companionship of happy mutual love have missed the best thing that life has to give." - Bertrand Russell
"Collective fear stimulates herd instinct, and tends to produce ferocity toward those who are not regarded as members of the herd." - Bertrand Russell
"It has been said that man is a rational animal. All my life I have been searching for evidence which could support this." - Bertrand Russell
"No one gossips about other people’s secret virtues." - Bertrand Russell
"We know very little, and yet it is astonishing that we know so much, and still more astonishing that so little knowledge can give us so much power." - Bertrand Russell

"The secret of happiness is very simply this: let your interests be as wide as possible, and let your reactions to the things and persons that interest you be as far as possible friendly rather than hostile." - Bertrand Russell
